revisions.rev: The '''EFI System partition''' is a [[partition (computing)|partition]] on a [[data storage device]] that is used by machines that adhere to the [[Extensible Firmware Interface]]. It contains the [[boot loader]] programs for all operating systems installed (in other partitions) on the device, device driver files (used by the [[firmware]] at boot time) for other devices, and system utility programs that are intended to be run before an [[operating system]] is booted.EFI specification, version 0.99 The EFI System Partition is formatted using a variant of the [[File Allocation Table|FAT]] format. The [[Globally Unique Identifier]] for the EFI System Partition in the [[GUID Partition Table]] scheme is C12A7328-F81F-11D2-BA4B-00A0C93EC93B. Its ID in the [[master boot record|MBR Partition Table]] scheme is 0xEF. Whether a disk contains an EFI System Partition is unrelated to the partition table scheme (GUID or MBR) that it uses. == Usage == === Windows === Microsoft recommends that when partitioning a disk, the EFI System Partition be the first partition on the disk.{{cite web|url=http://www.microsoft.com/whdc/device/storage/GPT_FAQ.mspx|work=Windows and GPT FAQ|title=EFI System Partition}} This is not a requirement of the EFI specification itself. On [[Windows XP]] 64-Bit Edition and later, access to the EFI System Partition is obtained by running the mountvol /s command. === AppleâIntel === On [[AppleâIntel architecture]] [[Macintosh]] computers, the EFI partition is initially blank and not used for booting.[http://refit.sourceforge.net/myths/ rEFIt: Myths and Facts About Intel Macs â Myth: Mac OS X requires a hidden EFI System Partition] However, the EFI partition is used as a staging area for firmware updates;{{cite web|url=http://support.apple.com/kb/HT2434|work=Apple Knowledgebase|title=Firmware updates for Intel-based Macs require a GUID partition scheme}} specifically, it places a firmware flash utility (EFI binary) and data file (FD â "Firmware Device"[http://download.intel.com/technology/efi/docs/pdfs/Fall07_EFIS002.pdf Zero to OS in a Flash]: "Firmware device (FD) is a persistent physical repository that contains firmware code and data.") in the directory EFI/APPLE/FIRMWARE which is then run when rebooting the system in "flash firmware" mode.[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=563052 ubunto forums: iMac EFI Firmware Update 1.2], September 29th, 2007 If deleted, the system will still boot, and the boot manager will still allow users to choose whether to start a [[Boot Camp (software)|Boot Camp]] partition or the default [[Mac OS X]], but firmware updates will fail. == See also== *[[BIOS Boot partition]] *[[System partition and boot partition]] *[[Windows To Go]] == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * {{cite web|url=http://www.uefi.org/specs/esp_registry|title=EFI System Partition Subdirectory Registry|work=UEFI}} — a registry of the subdirectories that lie below the /EFI directory on an EFI System Partition {{DEFAULTSORT:Efi System Partition}} [[Category:Computer file systems]] [[Category:Booting]]
